Description: Fragment of a curved marble ovolo moulding. The one sided curved three quarter ovolo moulding is accompanied on both sides by a sharp labium. The adjoining surface is on the inner side of the curve concave, on the outer convex. On the convex outer side ‘lies’ a ca. 5 mm ‘deep’ and smooth relief layer. The radius of 16,6 cm of the preserved circle curve was reconstructed, by means of a stencil. The shape of the attached ornament is no longer visible. On the convex outer side of the curve traces of red paint was found. Light grey marble
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: The radius of 16,6 cm of the preserved circle curve was reconstructed, by means of a stencil. The shape of the attached ornament is no longer visible. Since the circle curve could also have been part of a volute, a connection of the fragment to a capital or an altar volute was considered. Because of the concave-convex surface and the thickness of the ‘shell’, such a connection could not have existed. Therefore no interpretation of this fragment could been made yet. Published (Koenigs 2007, 335 Cat. 29)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B431)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.29, p.335, pl. 21)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.38) (Phase 3)
